My message during today's @OversightDems meeting:

Americans need help. It doesn’t matter if they’re conservative or liberal. It doesn’t matter if they live in a big city, a suburb, or a small rural town. They are all struggling—and will continue to struggle—unless we act now. http://pbs.twimg.com/ext_tw_video_thumb/1360375865876484096/pu/img/lowh1YzfQB625rF6.jpg https://video.twimg.com/ext_tw_video/1360375865876484096/pu/vid/480x270/L9GrB62ckkNs1FE5.mp4?tag=10

30/x One bright side of a long and “robust” mark-up: hearing from new voices, like Byron Donalds and Yvette Harrell. Junior members question last and rarely address the full House, so a mark-up is a real chance to hear their perspectives. I may not agree, but I’m listening. 👂

29/x Rep. Comer just lauded his “colleague from Florida who ran to fight for taxpayers of Florida.” He was referring to Rep. Nancy Mace, who represents South Carolina. It's been a long day for everyone. 😬
28/x Rep. Nancy Mace (R-SC) used her time to talk about how she serves on 3 committees in Congress and that she has noticed that Democrats and Republicans are not voting together.
27/x As is sadly typical, the mark-up has devolved into both sides grumbling that this mark-up is taking too long—and blaming each other for that.

26/x Admittedly, a couple amendments (of the 40!) were on topic. For example, we debated whether smaller cities should receive funds directly from the U.S. Treasury via a not yet established system, or should receive funds via distributions to each state, as prior bills did.

25/x So far, we have had amendments filed on a range of favorite hot button Republican issues: Keystone XL, Paris Climate Accord, mail-in ballots, abortion, fracking, immigration, census data, etc. None of these are relevant to state and local government funding or the pandemic.
24/x We are nearing the 7th hour of this mark-up. Still, many of the amendments being offered are unrelated to the main point of the legislation: funding for state and local governments.
@OtterFi You can find a list of members here: https://oversight.house.gov/members

23/x Chairs particularly need a lot of stamina to run a hearing—they must remain in place and preside, or else ask someone to chair temporarily. I’ve never gotten to do it but think it looks like fun. Probably less fun remotely when the actual gavel stays in the hearing room...
22/x We are taking a 5 minute recess. This is recess in the same sense as in school. It’s a chance to take a break.

21/x I carry 3 cell phones and an iPad and try to have at least two of the devices fully charged at the start of the morning for exactly this reason.

I challenge tech innovators to make a battery that can hold up to the partisanship of Congress!
20/x As this mark-up goes on, everybody on a device is plugging in. I started fully charged, plugged in a few hours ago, but video takes so much battery that I’m down to 3%!

19/x “En bloc” is when we vote on several amendments together as a package. It's most common when amendments are similar in nature or less controversial. For example, this morning, several amendments tried to limit how states and localities could spend the proposed COVID relief.

18/x Republicans have requested recorded votes for all their amendments from the 3 hours of mark-up so far. Committee rules say we can roll these to a fixed time. Several amendments were taken together “en bloc.” What is “en bloc?”
17/x Any member can then request a recorded vote. What is a “recorded vote?” It's where the clerk of the Committee calls each member by name and we respond either “yes/aye” or “no/nay.”

16/x We paused considering amendments to switch to voting. This is actually the second vote on each amendment. Right after debate, we take a “voice” vote (everyone who agrees says “yes”). The Chair then rules, normally for the party with more members. In this case, the Democrats.
15/x Second observation: “Go on mute” is my new phrase for when my kids need to be quiet. I’ve been saying “turn down your volume knob,” but sometimes I really mean “silent!”

14/x Chair @RepMaloney again reminds members to “go on mute” because of background noise. Two observations here: (1) this problem isn't limited to virtual hearings. People often discuss amendments among themselves in-person. This can be productive but can also become distracting.

13/x Will it go 24 hours? Probably not. Some amendments may not be raised. My best guess is 10 hours. This kind of uncertainty is why being a scheduler is the hardest job on the Hill. And note: you can tune in at home (but don’t hold that against me...) https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aNFVKdlw3lw&feature=youtu.be

12/x The second factor is how much debate occurs. After the amendment’s author speaks, a member from the other party is recognized for up to 5 minutes, and then it alternates back and forth between members, for 5 minutes each. Then also add openings and votes. See whiteboard ⬇️ http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EuDKaqqVcAIdboC.jpg

11/x Why does mark-up take hours? The first factor is the number of amendments. The more proposed changes, the longer the process takes. Each person who puts forth an amendment is given 5 minutes to explain their amendment. Today, we expect about 40 amendments.

10/x Amendments must be "germane," i.e. fall under the committee's jurisdiction to amend the bill. An amendment offered today to expand paid leave for Capitol Police isn't germane. While we have to vote no, I hope my colleagues overseeing the Capitol Police consider this measure.

9/x Rep. Grothman is making an amendment that would say something the bill already says. Regardless of one’s beliefs, this is just wasting time. It doesn't improve the bill. Our communities have waited and waited for help; now they have to wait through these redundant amendments.

8/x One GOP mayor wrote to me: "communities like mine are not asking for a 'bail-out.' Local governments do not expect the federal government to make up for every loss of... revenue. Instead, we seek an additional lifeline... to put off and ultimately avoid last resort options."
7/x I've heard from nearly every city in my district, all but one of which has a Republican mayor and Republican majority city council, that they strongly support local funding.

6/x Chair @RepMaloney's opening includes letters from mayors in Republican districts, including Bob Gibbs' and Jim Jordan's, asking for help. Example of non-responsive Congressional speechifying: top Republican says sending resources to state and local governments is “wasteful.”

5/x Great question from comments: What is a mark up?

Answer: When a bill is introduced, it's given a number and referred to relevant committees. We'll get feedback from stakeholders. Sometimes we'll have hearings on the bills. Then, we debate and amend (or "mark up") the bill.

4/x Does wearing glasses help you do good oversight? Maybe. Proud to be part of the club. 🤓

(PS This is my favorite picture of Jim Jordan ever taken.) http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EuCvFCbU0AMR0Y8.jpg

3/x That isn’t to say Congress is ready to go full virtual Senate like in Star Wars, although a girl can dream. We just had staff tell a member they weren't on video. “I don’t know what to do. I see a button ‘start my video.’ Do you think I should hit that to start my video?” 🤦‍♀️

2/x The hearing is virtual (we use WebEx). It was to start at 12pmEST, and I logged on 3 entire minutes early, seeking extra credit for good attendance. Virtual hearings save time because we don't have to wait 30 or more minutes for members to physically get to the hearing room.

I'm looking forward to my new appointment on the Appropriations Subcommittee on transportation to ensure we keep making progress on important infrastructure issues like these.

As always, had a great, productive conversation with Commissioner Paul Edwards from Garrett County today. We've been working together for years on improving the infrastructure in Garrett County on 219 and expanding broadband.
I'm going to continue to have these conversations and make sure we are making strong progress towards ending this pandemic.
Hope is on the way. We are making steps and progress towards getting more vaccines and getting those vaccines into the arms of Marylanders, Americans, and others around the world.
Important work is being done in Gaithersburg for key parts of the vaccine production and antibody production that will be critical in ending this pandemic.

I'm also proud of the work done in Maryland's 6th District in Gaithersburg by the clinical and manufacturing supply chain experts who are playing a critical role in the global leadership and manufacturing of the vaccine.

Because of the Defense Production Act enacted by the Biden Administration, we will have an additional 300 million vaccines from @AstraZeneca that are all manufactured and produced in the U.S. This will likely be approved in the next month.

My main focus right now is making sure every Marylander and American who wants a vaccine can get one. Today, I met with @AstraZeneca to talk about the development of their vaccine and how soon it will get emergency use authorization.

NY-14, have other questions? Reply below or shoot us a note https://ocasio-cortez.house.gov/contact

What is being done to increase vaccine supply? 

The U.S. just purchased 200M more doses, a 50% supply increase.

As of this week, the federal government is also sending doses directly to retail pharmacies.  In NYC, those doses are for ages 65+. More at http://Vaccinefinder.nyc.gov.

The next eligible group is people with preexisting conditions. When can they schedule their vaccinations?

You can call on 2/14 but you wont be scheduled until 2/15. See here for eligible conditions & required documentation: https://www.governor.ny.gov/news/governor-cuomo-announces-new-yorkers-comorbidities-and-underlying-conditions-can-make

Are vaccines safe? And are they still effective given the new COVID variants?

Overwhelmingly yes.  Numerous studies have found the vaccine to be safe & effective against various COVID-19 strains. Those prone to severe allergic reactions should speak with their doctor.

How do I schedule a vaccine? 

For City-run sites, including Citi Field, go to http://Vaccinefinder.nyc.gov or call 1-800-VAX-NYC4 

For State-run sites, go to http://am-i-eligible.covid19vaccine.health.ny.gov/ or call 1-833-NYS-4-VAX 

For Yankee Stadium, go to http://SomosVaccinations.com, 1-833-SOMOSNY

How much do vaccines cost?

Vaccines are free of charge.

Do I still have to wear a mask after I get the vaccine?

Yes! Experts need more time to understand the protection that COVID-19 vaccines provide before deciding to change recommendations on mask use or social distancing.

What is being done to increase vaccine sites in NY-14? 

We worked to bring a temporary site to First Baptist Church of E. Elmhurst, serving 500+. We have also identified for the state other possible temporary sites, including the NY Hall of Science and Lehman High School Campus.

This week, we held a town hall on the COVID vaccine. Here were some of the FAQs:

Who's eligible?

The groups listed here are eligible regardless of documentation status. No immigration nor citizenship information will be taken at the vaccine site. https://www1.nyc.gov/site/doh/covid/covid-19-vaccine-eligibility.page

That's why I'm proud to re-introduce the 1908 Springfield Race Riot National Monument Act with @SenatorDurbin.

We can't let this important moment in our nation's history go unrecognized or let it be forgotten. Black history is American history.

Since its founding on this day 112 years ago, the @NAACP has played a pivotal role in helping us expel white supremacy and champion civil rights.

One way we can help their work is to learn from our history by memorializing events like the 1908 Springfield Race Riots.

In 1908, white residents in Springfield, IL, burned down Black businesses and homes. They attacked hundreds and murdered six for no other reason than the color of their skin.

After this horror, a handful of determined citizens set out to form the @NAACP to help us rebuild.

Our nation has so much to thank the @NAACP for as we mark the 112th anniversary of its founding. 

It’s an origin story of fierce leadership in one of our nation’s darkest hours, and today is as good a time as any to share that story far and wide.

BUT WHAT DOES THIS HAVE TO DO WITH COVID RELIEF? 

American workers cannot afford any more delays–like when GOP inaction caused a lapse in critical unemployment assistance last year. 
 
The 2021 budget resolution provides another path for #COVID relief.⤵️https://budget.house.gov/publications/report/budget-resolution-and-reconciliation-alternative-path-american-rescue-plan

DOES THAT MEAN BUDGET RECONCILIATION IS A PARTISAN PROCESS? 

Not at all. Budget reconciliation doesn’t preclude bipartisan action & Republicans can choose to support the bill. 

But it ensures Congress can deliver @POTUS' #AmericanRescuePlan & the #COVID relief our nation needs.

REPUBLICANS ARE COMPLAINING ABOUT DEMS USING BUDGET RECONCILIATION. HAVE THEY USED IT BEFORE?
 
Yes. The GOP used reconciliation to pass their #GOPTaxScam & tried to use it to dismantle the ACA. 

Dems are using it to deliver crucial #COVID relief. ⤵️https://budget.house.gov/publications/report/budget-resolution-and-reconciliation-alternative-path-american-rescue-plan

WHAT ABOUT THE SENATE🐦RULE?
The Byrd Rule limits extraneous provisions from being included in reconciliation bills. It also prevents the use of reconciliation to move legislation that’s unrelated to spending or taxes. 
Get more info on the Byrd Rule here⤵️https://budget.house.gov/publications/fact-sheet/budget-reconciliation-basics

HOW DOES BUDGET RECONCILIATION WORK IN THE HOUSE? 

The budget resolution's reconciliation framework sets a budgetary target. Cmtes with jurisdiction draft & report legislation in line with these targets to @HouseBudgetDems. 

Then we package the bill & bring it to the floor.

SO, CAN IT BE USED TO FAST TRACK EVERYTHING? 

No, budget reconciliation can only include changes to spending, revenues, or the debt limit. Plus, only certain amendments can be offered.  

Learn more about the limits of budget reconciliation here.⤵️ https://budget.house.gov/publications/fact-sheet/budget-reconciliation-basics

FIRST, WHAT IS BUDGET RECONCILIATION? 

It’s a tool – a special process – that makes certain bills easier to pass in the Senate. For example, instead of needing 60 votes, it only needs a simple majority. 

Also, budget reconciliation bills cannot be filibustered.

In addition to his writing, Mr. Bunch has held numerous teaching positions at universities across the country, including American University in Washington, D.C., the University of Massachusetts in Dartmouth and George Washington University in Washington, D.C. (7/8)

Mr. Bunch is also a widely published author, having written on topics ranging from the black military experience, the American presidency and all-black towns in the American West to diversity in museum management and the impact of funding and politics on American museums. (6/8)

Thanks to Mr. Bunch's vision, optimism, and determination, the museum has welcomed more than 6 million visitors since it opened in September 2016 and compiled a collection of 40,000 objects that are housed in the first “green building” on the National Mall. (5/8)

Mr. Bunch previously served as director of the Smithsonian’s National Museum of African American History and Culture, a job he started in 2005 with one staff member, no collections, no funding and no site for a museum. (4/8)

RT @HouseBudgetDems WHAT ABOUT THE SENATE🐦RULE?
The Byrd Rule limits extraneous provisions from being included in reconciliation bills. It also prevents the use of reconciliation to move legislation that’s unrelated to spending or taxes. 
Get more info on the Byrd Rule here⤵️https://budget.house.gov/publications/fact-sheet/budget-reconciliation-basics

RT @HouseBudgetDems HOW DOES BUDGET RECONCILIATION WORK IN THE HOUSE? 

The budget resolution's reconciliation framework sets a budgetary target. Cmtes with jurisdiction draft & report legislation in line with these targets to @HouseBudgetDems. 

Then we package the bill & bring it to the floor.

RT @HouseBudgetDems SO, CAN IT BE USED TO FAST TRACK EVERYTHING? 

No, budget reconciliation can only include changes to spending, revenues, or the debt limit. Plus, only certain amendments can be offered.  

Learn more about the limits of budget reconciliation here.⤵️ https://budget.house.gov/publications/fact-sheet/budget-reconciliation-basics

RT @HouseBudgetDems FIRST, WHAT IS BUDGET RECONCILIATION? 

It’s a tool – a special process – that makes certain bills easier to pass in the Senate. For example, instead of needing 60 votes, it only needs a simple majority. 

Also, budget reconciliation bills cannot be filibustered.
